bioghist.p: The second degree-granting unit inaugurated at Villanova University was the College of Engineering, which began instruction in 1905 under the name of the School of Technology. Dr. A. B. Carpenter was hired in 1904 to organize and direct the school. In 1908 an undergraduate program in Mechanical Engineering was established, and in 1909 the first engineering bachelors degrees were awarded. An undergraduate program in Chemical Engineering was established in 1919. In the years following the Second World War, the College expanded its degree offerings to the masters level, establishing graduate programs in each of its four engineering departments. A fifth undergraduate degree program, in Computer Engineering, was added in 1993. In the 1990s, research units were established in the areas of advanced communications and environmental engineering.

scopecontent.p: The records of the College of Engineering include records of the Dean of the College and records of programs and departments within the College. The papers of the Dean of the College of Engineering consist of administrative records, reports, and printed materials. Administrative records include a 1939 chemical engineering curriculum; information on the "Engineering personnel service" (a career preparation program), 1939; and a faculty and student directory of the College from 1980-1981. Reports range in date from 1905 to 1990 and cover a variety of topics, including the Collegeâ€™s marking system, statistics on the College, proposals for expansion of the facilities, and curriculum and program reviews and self-studies. Printed materials include brochures for the College, posters for the Graduate Studies program, a Sophomore class notebook from 1924-1925, and other items. Records of the Electrical and Computer Engineering Department include a policy and procedure manual, faculty profiles, annual department reports (1985-1991), and proposals for Bachelor of Science and Doctor in Philosophy degrees in Electrical Engineering. Records of the Mechanical Engineering Department include laboratory instruction manuals, homework and examination problems, course notes, and a student notebook.
